sen.j: 久世 通式（くぜ みちのり、文禄2年（1593年） - 寛永5年（1628年））は江戸時代初期の公卿。
sen.e: KUZE Michinori (1593-1628) was a court noble in the early Edo Period.
KUZE Michinori (1593-1628) was a court noble during the early Edo Period.
KUZE Michinori (1593-1628) was a court noble during the early Edo Period.
He was KOGA Atsumichi's son.
He was KOGA Atsumichi's son.
He was KOGA Atsumichi's son.

sen.j: 久世通武と誤写されている文書も多い。
sen.e: In many documents his name is erroneously written as KUZE Michitake (通武)
sen.cmt: 久世通武→KUZE Michitake (通武) [正しい読み方が不明です]
sen.e: In many documents his name was erroneously written as KUZE Michitake (通武)
In many documents his name was erroneously written as KUZE Michitake (通武)
His origin
His origin
His origin

sen.j: 久我家19代敦通の次男通式を初代とする京都久世家は村上源氏の流れを組む羽林家の公家である。
sen.e: The Kyoto Kuze family is a court noble belonging to the House of Urin (holding military ranks) and a descendent of the Murakami-Genji (Minamoto clan), and Michinori KUZE was the first generation of the Kuze family and the second son of Atsumichi KOGA., who was the 19th generation of the Koga family.

The Kyoto Kuze family is are court nobles belonging to the House of Urin (holding military ranks) and are descendents of the Murakami-Genji (Minamoto clan), and Michinori KUZE was the first generation of the Kuze family and the second son of Atsumichi KOGA., who was the 19th generation of the Koga family.

The Kyoto Kuze family are court nobles belonging to the House of Urin (holding military ranks) and are descendents of the Murakami-Genji (Minamoto clan), and Michinori KUZE was the first generation of the Kuze family and the second son of Atsumichi KOGA., who was the 19th generation of the Koga family.
sen.cmt: isを取り除きました。ピリオドの前のスペースを取り除きました。

sen.j: 久我家から分岐した公家諸家としては、久世家の他に中院家、六条家、岩倉家、千種家、東久世家、梅渓家、愛宕家、植松家の8家がある。
sen.e: In addition to the Kuze family, there are eight court noble families separated from the Koga family; those are: Nakanoin family, Rokujo family, Iwakura family, Chigusa family, Higashikuze family, Umetani family, Atago family, and Uematsu family.

In addition to the Kuze family, there are eight court noble families separated from the Koga family; they are: the Nakanoin family, the Rokujo family, the Iwakura family, the Chigusa family, the Higashikuze family, the Umetani family, the Atago family, and the Uematsu family.

In addition to the Kuze family, there are eight court noble families separated from the Koga family; they are: the Nakanoin family, the Rokujo family, the Iwakura family, the Chigusa family, the Higashikuze family, the Umetani family, the Atago family and the Uematsu family.
sen.cmt: andの前の,を除去しました。

sen.e: Career
Career
Career

sen.j: 通式が久我家から分家して久世家を興した時期は明確でないが、通式は元和 (日本)5年（1619年）10月に所領として山城国乙訓郡下久世村において二百石を新知されている。
sen.e: The time in which Michinori formed the Kuze family separating from the Koga family is not clearly known, but in October 1619, Michinori was granted a shoryo (territory) that yielded 200-koku (36.078 cubic meters of crop yield) at Shimokuze Village, Otsukuni Country, Yamashiro Province.
sen.cmt: 二百石→200-koku (36.078 cubic meters of crop yield)としました。
sen.e: The time in which Michinori formed the Kuze family, that separated from the Koga family, is not clearly known, but in October 1619, Michinori was granted a shoryo (territory) that yielded 200-koku (36.078 cubic meters of crop yield) at Shimokuze Village, Otsukuni Country, Yamashiro Province.

The time in which Michinori formed the Kuze family, that separated from the Koga family, is not clearly known, but in November 1619, Michinori was granted a shoryo (territory) that yielded 200-koku (36.078 cubic meters of crop yield) at Shimokuze Village, Otsukuni County, Yamashiro Province.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に変更しました。CountryをCountyに変更しました。

sen.j: 通式が肥後藩主細川忠興の長男細川忠隆（廃嫡後は長岡休無）の三女福姫（1609-1635）を正室にした由縁で、福姫死後も助成米が細川氏から送られている。
sen.e: Since he took the third daughter of Tadataka HOSOKAWA (after the disinheritance, he called himself NAGAOKA Kyumu), Fukuhime (Princess Fuku) (1609-1635) as his lawful wife, and as Tadataka was the first son of the lord of Higo domain, Tadaoki HOSOKAWA, even after Fukuhime's death, he continued to be granted the yield of rice from the Hosokawa clan.
sen.cmt: 「助成米が細川氏から送られている」→助成米の定訳不明：he continued to be granted the yield of rice from the Hosokawa clanとしました。
sen.e: Since he took the third daughter of Tadataka HOSOKAWA (after the disinheritance, he called himself NAGAOKA Kyumu), Fukuhime (Princess Fuku) (1609-1635) as his lawful wife, and as Tadataka was the first son of the lord of Higo domain, Tadaoki HOSOKAWA, even after Fukuhime's death, he continued to be granted the yield of rice from the Hosokawa clan.

Since he took the third daughter of Tadataka HOSOKAWA (after the disinheritance, he called himself NAGAOKA Kyumu), Fukuhime (Princess Fuku) (1609-1635) as his lawful wife, and as Tadataka was the first son of the lord of Higo domain, Tadaoki HOSOKAWA, even after Fukuhime's death, he continued to be granted the yield of rice from the Hosokawa clan.

sen.j: また細川忠隆死去にあたりその遺志として、子の久世通俊に助成米として年百石が贈られるようになった。
sen.e: And when Tadataka HOSOKAWA died, according to his will, Michinori's son Michitoshi KUZE succeeded to the privilege of receiving the grant of 100-koku (18.039 cubic meters of crop yield).
sen.cmt: 助成米として年百石贈られる→助成米の定訳不明：the privilege of receiving the grant of 100-koku (18.039 cubic meters of crop yield)としました。
sen.e: And when Tadataka HOSOKAWA died, according to his will, Michinori's son Michitoshi KUZE succeeded to the privilege of receiving the grant of 100-koku (18.039 cubic meters of crop yield).
And when Tadataka HOSOKAWA died, according to his will, Michinori's son Michitoshi KUZE succeeded to the privilege of receiving the grant of 100-koku (18.039 cubic meters of crop yield).

sen.j: 久世通式以後は、通式－久世通俊－久世通音と続き、現在まで22代続く。
sen.e: After Michinori KUZE, the family was succeeded by Michitoshi KUZE, Michioto KUZE and others, and it can be counted up to the 22nd generation since Michinori.
After Michinori KUZE, the family was succeeded by Michitoshi KUZE, Michioto KUZE and others, and it can be counted up to the 22nd generation since Michinori.
After Michinori KUZE, the family was succeeded by Michitoshi KUZE, Michioto KUZE and others, and it can be counted up to the 22nd generation since Michinori.

sen.j: 代々近衛府の役に任じられ、久世通夏以後はいずれも権大納言に昇進。
sen.e: From generation to generation the family took charge of Konoefu (Division of Inner Palace Guards), and since the generation of Michinatsu KUZE, all of the family heads were promoted to Dainagon (chief councilor of state).

From generation to generation the family took charge of Konoefu (Division of Inner Palace Guards), and since the generation of Michinatsu KUZE, all of the family heads were promoted to Dainagon (chief councilor of state).

From generation to generation the family took charge of Konoefu (Division of Inner Palace Guards), and since the generation of Michinatsu KUZE, all of the family heads were promoted to Gon Dainagon (provisional chief councilor of state).
sen.cmt: Dainagon (chief councilor of state)をGon Dainagon (provisional major counselor)に変更しました。major counselor→chief councilor of state

sen.e: In the Meiji Period the title of viscount was granted.
During the Meiji Period the title of viscount was granted.
During the Meiji Period the title of viscount was granted.

sen.j: 膨大な山城国京都久世家文書が明治大学などに残され、国文学研究資料館などで研究されている。
sen.e: Numerous documents derived from the Kyoto Kuze family of Yamashiro Province are kept in Meiji University, etc., and the study on the family is carried out in the National Institute of Japanese Literature and others.

Numerous documents derived from the Kyoto Kuze family of Yamashiro Province are kept in Meiji University, etc., and the study on the family is carried out in the National Institute of Japanese Literature and others.

Numerous documents derived from the Kyoto Kuze family of Yamashiro Province are kept in Meiji University, etc., and the study on the family is carried out in the National Institute of Japanese Literature and others.
